channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
item.description: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Using different legal authorities, President Trump plans to impose a 10 percent global tariff and open investigations into certain, unspecified countries’ unfair trade practices.

item.title: Even After Supreme Court Ruling, Trump Insists He Can Do as He Wishes
item.description: President Trump showed open contempt for the court, calling the justices who voted against his tariffs “fools and lap dogs.” He quickly imposed new levies using legal powers still available to him.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the James S. Brady Briefing Room at the White House on Friday. With him are the United States solicitor general, D. John Sauer, left, and the commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick.

item.title: With Tariff Changes, Consumers May Be Stuck in a Waiting Game
item.description: Some companies could decide to temper price increases, but the effect would take time to materialize.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Economists cautioned that the Supreme Court ruling would probably not lower sticker prices right away, if at all.

item.title: Bench Presses, Pull Ups … Kid Rock? The White House Had a Very Manly Week.
item.description: President Trump’s top cabinet officials are pumping iron in public.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

item.title: Longtime Virginia Lawyer Chosen by Judges as U.S. Attorney, and Then Fired
item.description: It was the second time this month that the administration had gotten rid of a top federal prosecutor appointed to his post by federal judges.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

item.title: C.I.A. Retracts Reports Flagged for Bias
item.description: Former officials said the documents were not examples of shoddy work and simply reflected the priorities of past administrations.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Ratcliffe, the C.I.A. director. The agency’s leadership has made moves to keep in step with President Trump.

item.title: U.S. Planes Land at Jordan Base, a Key Hub for Planning Possible Iran Strikes
item.description: At least 60 attack aircraft are parked at the base, which has become a key hub for U.S. military planning for possible strikes on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen, Christoph Koettl and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Hungary Poses Unexpected Hurdle to Europe’s 90-Billion Euro Loan to Ukraine
item.description: While the delay may prove to be procedural, Hungary signaled that it could cause problems as the European Union works to send money to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Michal Cizek/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Hungarian foreign minister, Peter Szijjarto, in Prague, Czech Republic, last month.

item.title: Ruben Ray Martinez Was Killed in an Undisclosed ICE Shooting in March, His Family Says
item.description: A 23-year-old American was shot last March in South Padre Island. ICE’s involvement in the shooting was not disclosed until this week.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra and Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Ronaldo Schemidt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The shooting last March occurred in South Padre Island, Texas.

item.title: These Skiers Cleared Out as Group That Would Be Hit by Avalanche Arrived
item.description: If the party had waited out the storm in their cabins, one of the skiers said, the outcome might have been different.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trail to Castle Peak near Donner Pass. At least eight backcountry skiers died this week in an avalanche in the Castle Peak area.

item.title: San José State University Graduate Is Found Dead in Tree Well at Lake Tahoe Resort
item.description: The recent graduate, 21, was on a trail in the Lake Tahoe region of California on Tuesday and did not return, prompting a search. His death is under investigation, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Jane Tyska/Bay Area News Group, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A skier was found dead at a California resort on Thursday, after he did not return from a black diamond run earlier in the week.

item.title: Bridge Owner Donated $1 Million to MAGA Group Before Trump Blasted Competitor
item.description: The PAC and the White House say the donation had nothing to do with President Trump’s tirade against a new bridge connecting Detroit and Windsor, Ontario.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Gordie Howe International Bridge under construction in Windsor, Ontario, in January 2024.

item.title: A Once Prominent American Statesman Faces Fallout From the Epstein Files
item.description: George Mitchell, a former Senate majority leader credited with bringing peace to Northern Ireland, is under renewed scrutiny over his association with Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/The New York Times
item.media:description: George Mitchell, shown in 2010, when he was special envoy to the Middle East, has come under renewed scrutiny for his ties to the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest Upends Royal Family’s Effort to Move Past His Scandal
item.description: King Charles III’s family, long rocked by infighting and grievous losses, is facing what could be the gravest threat to its moral authority in more than a generation.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Phil Noble/Reuters
item.media:description: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, center, the brother of King Charles III, after leaving a police station on Thursday.

item.title: Epstein Scandal Leaves Some Young Trump Voters Feeling Betrayed
item.description: Drawn to President Trump for his pledge to take down the political elite, some of his young constituents say he has failed them.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Taylor Pemberton
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: As President Trump and prominent right-wing voices try to downplay the revelations of the Epstein files, some young conservatives are losing faith in the Make America Great Again movement.

item.title: A.I. Isn’t Coming for Every White-Collar Job. At Least Not Yet.
item.description: Tech workers are increasingly worried that the artificial intelligence they are building will replace them. But some are optimistic that it is just one more tool to work with.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Adam Glanzman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Though powerful, code generators still require extensive oversight, according to researchers and programmers.

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot Survived Mass Rape. Now She’s Looking to the Future.
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot stayed silent after dozens of men were convicted of raping her. Now, Ms. Pelicot is finding peace by publicizing her ordeal and explaining how she survived it.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.category: A Hymn to Life: Shame Has to Change Sides (Book)
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: L.G.B.T.Q. Clubs in Some Texas Schools Can’t Be Banned, Judge Says
item.description: A Texas law passed last year was the first in the nation to explicitly ban clubs based on gender identity in K-12 schools. The judge blocked its enforcement in three school districts.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Kaylee Greenlee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Texas law also prohibits employees at K-12 public and charter schools from “assisting” students with socially transitioning between genders.

item.title: Court Clears Way for Louisiana Law Requiring Ten Commandments in Classrooms
item.description: A federal appeals court vacated a temporary block on the 2024 law, tossing a previous decision that called it “plainly unconstitutional.”
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Hilary Scheinuk/The Advocate, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Liz Murrill, the Louisiana attorney general, speaks alongside Gov. Jeff Landry during a news conference regarding the state’s Ten Commandments in Baton Rouge, La., in 2024.

item.title: Another Winter Storm Could Deliver More Snow to the Northeast This Weekend
item.description: Forecasts on Friday began to make another major snowstorm look far more likely. Snow is expected to begin falling Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recent snow in Brooklyn. Is more on the way? Maybe.

item.title: Will the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling Curb Trump?
item.description: What does this mean for the president, the economy — and your bank account?
item.dc:creator: Binyamin Appelbaum, Josh Barro, Catherine Rampell and Stephen Stromberg
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times

item.title: Whitewashing ‘Wuthering Heights’
item.description: It’s time to end the era of colorblind casting.
item.dc:creator: Naveen Kumar
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: China’s ‘King of Banned Films’ Wants to Change the Subject
item.description: Acclaimed overseas for defying censors, Lou Ye is more interested in reaching Chinese audiences, as he holds up a cinematic mirror to their lives in modern China.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chinese director Lou Ye, at his studio in Beijing in November.

item.title: Police Chief Placed Millions in Bets as He Embezzled, Investigators Say
item.description: Karl R. Jacobson was arrested and accused of stealing from city coffers as he placed $4.5 million in online bets. He resigned in January, when the accusations first surfaced.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: City of New Haven, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Haven Police Chief Karl Jacobson is charged with two counts of larceny in the first degree by defrauding a public community, according to the state’s attorney.

item.title: Christopher S. Wren, Times Bureau Chief in Hostile Lands, Dies at 89
item.description: Over three decades, he reported from Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and elsewhere and wrote well-received books based on his reporting, including one about his globe-trotting cat.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Wren in an undated photo. Explaining why he went into journalism, he said, “I wanted to find a job where I could go out and satisfy my curiosity and have somebody pay for it.”

item.title: Dog Poop Wars: In New York, the Snow Is Foul, and So Is the Discourse
item.description: As melting snow reveals weeks’ worth of uncollected dog waste, frustration at the state of the sidewalks has boiled over.
item.dc:creator: John Leland
item.media:credit: Amy Lombard for The New York Times
